on big disks, the 5% overhead is a bit much
dangerous to reduce it.
if metadata operations run out of space seriously nasty things will happen.
I think so, yes.  For one thing the space needed by a full fsck is proportional to the size of the partition.
but how big are these ops, not 10GB at a time, surely?
that's hard to answer as it depends on the actual state of the file system.  But if you have 190 gigs of data, 10 gigs of scratch for an fsck is certainly not obviously too large
Certainly, I would never reduce it unless for some odd reason I absolutely positively have to have that space and can't clean anything old out.
iirc the manpage for tunefs mentions that 5% might be overkill for large file systems
might.  Might means might not.
and unless you are at 100% full, why reduce it?
